protocol_name: Evidence-Based Information Halves the Influence of Physicians’ Non-Evidence-Based Cancer Screening Recommendations
protocol_name_html: Evidence-Based Information Halves the Influence of Physicians’ Non-Evidence-Based Cancer Screening Recommendations
description: Randomized survey study to test whether evidence-based patient information about cancer screening provided upfront to people make them less likely to simply follow a non-evidence-based recommendation of their physician
protocol_affiliation: *Max Planck Institute for Human Development, Lentzeallee 94, 14195 Berlin (Germany), **German Institute for Economic Research and Max Planck Institute for Human Development, Lentzeallee 94, 14195 Berlin (Germany)
manuscript_citation: Wegwarth O, Wagner GG, Gigerenzer G, Can facts trump unconditional trust? Evidence-based information halves the influence of physicians’ non-evidence-based cancer screening recommendations. PLoS ONE 12(8). doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0183024
keywords: Evidence-based medicine, risk communication, statistical literacy, patient counselling
authors: Odette Wegwarth*, Gert G. Wagner**, Gerd Gigerenzer*

authors_list.name: Odette Wegwarth*
authors_list.affiliation: *Max Planck Institute for Human Development, Lentzeallee 94, 14195 Berlin (Germany), **German Institute for Economic Research and Max Planck Institute for Human Development, Lentzeallee 94, 14195 Berlin (Germany)
